Description
These are methods to create, access and change keys and their values into the Linux Registry (see registry7). To make more detailed registry's key/value manipulation, the key*() methods are also available (see key3).
Before starting to access the Registry, you must call registryOpen, and after finishing working with it, you can call registryClose. After calling registryClose you can still manipulate the Key objects you gathered, but you'll not be able to commit your changes. So the normal usage of the Registry is:
Call registryOpen() Get and manipulate keys Call registryClose() to free unused resources Work with the keys thrughout your application registryOpen(), save changed keys, registryClose()
regitryGetChildKeys is the best way to get all keys that matters to your application. It will look for keys hierarchically bellow parentKeyName and return a KeySet in returned. You can control the behavior ORing the following options:
RG_O_RECURSIVE Retrieve also the keys under the child keys, recursively. The rg1 ls command, with switch -R uses this option.
RG_O_DIR By default, folder keys will not be returned because they don't have values and exist only to define hierarchy. Use this option if you need them to be included in the returned KeySet.
RG_O_NOVALUE Do not include in returned the regular value keys. The resulting KeySet will be only the skeleton of the tree.
RG_O_STATONLY Only stat2 the keys; do not retrieve the value, comment and key data type. The resulting keys will be empty and usefull only for informational purposes. The rg1 ls command, without the -v switch uses this option.
RG_O_INACTIVE Will make it not ignore inactive keys. So returned will be filled also with inactive keys. See registry7 to understand how inactive keys work.
RG_O_SORT Will sort keys alphabetically by their names.
regitryGetChildKeys returns zero (0) in case of success, or a negative number, and errno is set.
registrySetKeys will save to disk the modified keys in ks KeySet.
registryGetValue and registrySetValue are shortcuts for getting and setting the keyName value. When Getting, it will copy to returned the value of the keyName key, unless maxSize is smaller then the number of bytes (including NULL termination) of the key's value. Then errno is set to ENOBUFS. Or key data type is Binary, and errno is set to RG_KEY_RET_TYPEMISMATCH. When Setting, it will check if keyName already exists. If so, permissions, key comment, etc will be kept. If not, the key will be created with current UID and GID, and access bits calculated from umask2. String values are allways stored as an UTF-8 encoded string, and the conversion is transparent and automatic. Both methods return negative values in case of failure (errno is set) or zero in case of success.
registryGetKeyByParent, registryGetKeyByParentKey, registryGetValueByParent, registrySetValueByParent have behavior similar to the above methods, and are provided for convenience. The desired key is formed by a parent name or key and a base name, so they'll internally concatenate the parent's and baseName.
registryLink will create a symbolic link key as keyName pointing to target. If target begins with system or user or wathever is returned by registryGetRootKeys, it is treated as a key name and translations apply. Otherwise, is is considered as a regular file path that can be absolute or relative.
registryRemove will try to remove the keyName key. It may fail due to permissions, or key inexistence. Removing a link key will remove the link and not the real key. On success, zero is returned, otherwise -1 and errno is set to whatever unlink2 or rmdir2 set it.
registryGetComment and registrySetComment act in the comment part of keyName (see registry7, section Key Meta Data). If keyName already exists it will keep everything but the comment untouched. If it doesn't, the key will be created. The comment is allways stored as an UTF-8 encoded text. This is completely transparent for the application.
registryGetKey receives the key object with the key name already set. It will look for it in the Registry, and fill it up with the key data and attributes it finds. Memory will be allocated to store all the data gathered. After using key, memory can be freed calling keyClose(key). On success, 0 is returned. -1 is returned on some failure, and errno is set to indicate the error. This methods are used when a more refined key manipulation actions must be done later with the key*() methods (see key3). Otherwise registryGetValue may be prefered.
The registryStatKey works in the same way, but the key is only stated. The key object will be filled only with UID, GID, access and modification times, access permissions. Nothing will be gathered regarding data type, key value and key comment.
registrySetKey will write the whole info from key to the physical storage. If the refered key already exists, it will be completely overwrited, including access permissions, UID, GID and comment. Note that only the super user can physically change things like the UID of a key. On success, 0 is returned, otherwise -1, and errno is set.
registryGetRootKeys is a starting point for Registry browsers. It will fill returned with the root keys that represent the Namespaces. They are usually system and user. Returns 0 on success, or -1 and errno is set.
